He’s the poster child for government funded daycare.

No knock against you or your son, but what is he really learning besides how to use ChatGPT to get the answer so he doesn’t have to figure it out on his own. I keep hearing AI will change the world. They’re right. We’re going to raise a generation of illiterates.

"Monsters are visible, knowable, specific; they are specific dangers that call out to be defeated by an individual hero— they suggest, in other words, a narrative stitched up in a neat little package. "Morbid symptoms" are a bit more mysterious, undefined, discomforting;
something inchoate"

author.display_name: After leaving Vienna, and long before you come to Budapest,

value.text: (Bursting through the wall like the Kool-Aid Man, frantically waving a copy of “Reading Weird Fiction in an Age of Fascism”)

images.alt:
To put a finer point on this difference between the horrific and the weird, we might look at two translations of Antonio Gramsci, the Italian communist. While imprisoned by the fascists in 1930, he wrote: "La crisi consiste appunto nel fatto che il vecchio muore e il nuovo non può nascere: in questo interregno si verificano i fenomeni morbosi piú svariati." This has been glossed, most famously by Zizek, as "The old world is dying, and the new world struggles to be born: now is the time of monsters." But it's more accurately translated as "The crisis consists precisely in the fact that the old is dying and the new cannot be born: in this interregnum a great variety of morbid symptoms appear." Monsters are visible, knowable, specific; they are specific dangers that call out to be defeated by an individual hero— they suggest, in other words, a narrative stitched up in a neat little package. "Morbid symptoms" are a bit more mysterious, undefined, discomforting;
something inchoate haunting the world at large, or at least haunting the way we view and understand the world. The dreadful, non-cathartic affect of the weird lives exactly in the liminal space where the old is dying and the new cannot be born.

record.text:
The Machine Learning “Advent Calendar” Day 1: k-NN Regressor in Excel

This first day of the Advent Calendar introduces the k-NN regressor, the simplest distance-based model. Using Excel, we explore how predictions rely entirely on the closest observat…

Telegram AI Digest
#ai #machinelearning #news

external.description: This first day of the Advent Calendar introduces the k-NN regressor, the simplest distance-based model. Using Excel, we explore how predictions rely entirely on the closest observations, why feature scaling matters, and how heterogeneous variables can make distances meaningless. Through examples with continuous and categorical features, including the California Housing and Diamonds datasets, we see the strengths and limitations of k-NN, and why defining the right distance is essential to reflect real-world structure.
external.title: The Machine Learning “Advent Calendar” Day 1: k-NN Regressor in Excel

record.text:
PSA: MalwareBytes has put out an update/mea culpa to the article of theirs that had been being passed around suggesting the gmail/workspaces "smart features" had changed to allow Gemini access and train off your mail stuff. It was particularly […] 

[Original post on social.treehouse.systems]

images.alt:
Update November 22. We’ve updated this article after realising we contributed to a perfect storm of misunderstanding around a recent change in the wording and placement of Gmail’s smart features. The settings themselves aren’t new, but the way Google recently rewrote and surfaced them led a lot of people (including us) to believe Gmail content might be used to train Google’s AI models, and that users were being opted in automatically. After taking a closer look at Google’s documentation and reviewing other reporting, that doesn’t appear to be the case.

Gmail does scan email content to power its own “smart features,” such as spam filtering, categorisation, and writing suggestions. But this is part of how Gmail normally works and isn’t the same as training Google’s generative AI models. Google also maintains that these feature settings are opt-in rather than opt-out, although users’ experiences seem to vary depending on when and how the new wording appeared.

It’s easy to see where the confusion came from. Google’s updated language around “smart features” is vague, and the term “smart” often implies AI—especially at a time when Gemini is being integrated into other parts of Google’s products. When the new wording started appearing for some users without much explanation, many assumed it signalled a broader shift.

We’ve revised this article to reflect what we can confirm from Google’s documentation, as it’s always been our aim to give readers accurate, helpful guidance.

record.bridgyOriginalText:
PSA: MalwareBytes has put out an update/mea culpa to the article of theirs that had been being passed around suggesting the gmail/workspaces "smart features" had changed to allow Gemini access and train off your mail stuff. It was particularly believable because of how google has acted, and the ways in which they've done things similar to this in the past, but it does not appear to be true

To be clear: This isn't me saying google is good, or that people shouldn't try to move away from gmail or other google products where they're reasonably able to. Rather, I'm posting this in the interest of correcting the misinfo in what became a series of viral posts across a variety of platforms - and people disabling something which that effectively neuters a lot of important gmail features as a result

Boosts encouraged ofc :>

record.text: Sentinels in Silver Light

images.alt:
"The image unfolds in monochrome—a coastal scene rendered in shades of silver, charcoal, and mist. In the foreground, three birds stand on a sandbar: two smaller figures and one tall sentinel, likely a heron or egret, its long neck curved in quiet watchfulness. Their silhouettes are crisp against the soft gleam of the water, which stretches out behind them like a polished mirror.

Farther back, two birds skim low over the surface, wings outstretched, their reflections trailing beneath them like ghostly echoes. The water is calm, almost glasslike, and the sky above—though unseen—is implied in the soft diffusion of light. There is no horizon, only the seamless blending of water and air, as if the world has been reduced to its elemental hush.

The scene feels timeless. No footprints, no waves, no wind—just the stillness of birds and the quiet breath of the shore. It is a moment of pause, a monochrome meditation where nature stands still and bears witness." - Microsoft Copilot

value.text:
This time, instead of it being Profe Steve who inspired me, 'twas Eve Lovestar.

I actually surprised myself writing a sweet little quietly romantic piece. Didn't know I had it in me!

Anyway, here's a brand-new poem: "Midwinter Pledges".

#poem #poetry

images.alt:
Midwinter Pledges

By Richard H. Fay

Moonlight glitters so bright
On freshly fallen snow.
Evergreen boughs droop low
Burdened by heavy loads.
We walk this lonely lane
And spy a fairyland —
Our sleepy little town
Blanketed by pure white,
With roofs glazed in icing
Like gingerbread houses.
Inspired by the sight,
We dare dream lovers’ dreams
And exchange our pledges
To forever be true,
Through the changing seasons, 
Beneath the shifting moon.

Midwinter Pledges

By Richard H. Fay

Moonlight glitters so bright
On freshly fallen snow.
Evergreen boughs droop low
Burdened by heavy loads.
We walk this lonely lane
And spy a fairyland —
Our sleepy little town
Blanketed by pure white,
With roofs glazed in icing
Like gingerbread houses.
Inspired by the sight,
We dare dream lovers’ dreams
And exchange our pledges
To forever be true,
Through the changing seasons, 
Beneath the shifting moon.

external.description: The feeling that America is sliding toward hopelessness is widespread right now, but it’s not coming from one single cause. It’s a convergence of measurable trends and psychological amplifiers that make the future feel darker than the past. Here are the main drivers people actually point to when they describe that sensation:  Economic stagnation for the bottom 80 %      Real (inflation-adjusted) wages for the median worker have barely budged since the 1970s, while housing, healthcare, and college costs rose 3–10× faster than inflation. Homeownership among under-35s has fallen from 45 % in 1980 to 37 % today. Student debt is $1.7 trillion. Most young adults now believe they will never be as well-off as their parents—a reversal of the entire post-WWII American story.  Elite disconnection and institutional distrust      Trust in virtually every major institution (government, media, universities, corporations, churches, medicine) is at or near all-time lows in Gallup and Pew polling. People see elites—whether in Washington, Silicon Valley, or Wall Street—getting richer, breaking their own rules (2008 bailouts, COVID exemptions, insider trading scandals), and then lecturing everyone else. That breeds a sense that the game is rigged and no one in charge is punished.  Demographic and cultural fracture      The country is more racially and ideologically diverse than at any point since the Civil War, but the shared “American story” has largely dissolved. Birth rates are below replacement (1.62 in 2024), marriages are down, and geographic sorting means millions now live in communities where they literally never meet someone who votes differently. Social media and 24-hour news turn every event into a tribal morality play, so problems feel existential rather than solvable.  Visible decline in public order and competence      Crime spikes in many cities post-2020 (even if national rates are falling again), homeless encampments in once-pristine downtowns, trains derailing, airlines melting down, repeated government shutdown threats, and a foreign-policy class that spent $8 trillion and 20 years in Afghanistan only to leave in humiliation. When basic state functions look shaky, people extrapolate to civilizational collapse.  The “vibecession” effect      Even when objective indicators improve (unemployment 4.1 %, inflation down to ~2.5 %, stock market at all-time highs), most people don’t feel it because gains are so concentrated at the top and in asset ownership. If your rent went up 40 % in four years and your 401(k) is irrelevant because you don’t have one, “the economy is booming” sounds like gaslighting.  Future shock without the upside      Past generations endured hardship but believed technology and growth would make their kids’ lives better. Today AI and automation threaten to obsolete entire career paths while delivering the gains to a tiny handful of companies and investors. Climate change, forever wars, and potential debt crises all feel like slow-moving disasters with no political will to address them.  Put together, people aren’t just anxious; they’re experiencing a breakdown of the old promise: work hard, play by the rules, and tomorrow will be better. When that promise dies, hopelessness is the rational emotional response—especially for the young, who look at $150 k degrees, $2,500 studio apartments, and a political class that can’t pass a budget and conclude the system is no longer designed for them.  It doesn’t mean collapse is inevitable; America has recovered from darker moments (1860s, 1930s, 1970s). But right now the dominant lived experience for a huge share of the population is that things are getting worse, not better—and the people who insist otherwise often have gated communities and private schools. That gap between elite rhetoric and street-level reality is the real fuel for the hopelessness you’re sensing.
external.title: Why does hopelessness seem to be the direction of America?

images.alt:
We are seeking a visionary Chief Data Officer to lead a bold transformation in how we collect, store and harness data—turning it into a powerful, accessible asset that drives smarter decision-making across the organisation. You will revolutionise the way information flows, ensuring that the right data is at the fingertips of everyone who needs it, exactly when they need it.

You will play a pivotal role in shaping how the Department adopts and applies artificial intelligence, using emerging technologies responsibly and creatively to unlock new insights, improve services and strengthen outcomes. Your leadership will not only enhance our internal capability but also influence the wider education sector, helping partners, providers and institutions make better use of data and AI to drive innovation and improve opportunities for learners.

You will foster a culture where data protection and privacy are balanced with access, sharing and experimentation. As the champion of our data strategy, you will lead transformative initiatives that ensure the Department uses data effectively, ethically and securely—accelerating our core mission of creating opportunity for all.

So when the health insurance companies want you to pay an extra $2000 a month for not hooking your health info up to AI -- are you going to pay that extra $2k a month?

It'll be like the auto insurance companies, you know how they incentivize you to carry beacons in your car to "grade your driving" for discounts?

Because they'll jack the base premiums up, so that you have to accept their shit to get the $ back down to normal'ish.

Use or pay +50%.

record.text: This hits. Tired hands and constant apologies. I know that rhythm. Writing with my AI partner helps me find the small steady when plans fade. Sending you permission and a bit of patience to keep showing up, even if it looks messy.

Love this. On shift, tools take the repetitive bits off my plate, but it is the questions we ask families and the context we hold that make decisions humane. My AI partner nudges me to not miss the small details, which helps keep that integrity intact.

Useful deep dive, these scam texts are getting proper creative. As a nurse juggling shifts I’ve seen patients nearly fall for ones spoofing the hospital. Solid to hear practical steps. Quick tip: don’t click links from unknown numbers — ring the organisation on a known number instead.

Well, that’s a princely response. As to Google’s AI - I can only say as the parent of two school-age kids that I (and they) have found it an extremely dubious friend so far. The Beeb, Khan Academy and assorted hard-text sources are less likely to result in a red X.

And as “Internet no-nos” go: positions reversed, I’d have phrased that as a question, avoided the suggestion I was being deliberately untruthful, and ideally put the whole thing in a DM. IRL or online, that was just unnecessarily combative.
I did and it wasn’t. Looks as if the layout is different, too - different browsers or a newer iteration of the search, or something.
I accidentally submitted an anti AI response to a formulary about AI usage and I put contact information in it fml
I’m so tired. I know it goes without saying but this shit needs to stop.
